Posts.Content: Hi Patricia Your dog comments made me laugh. We have a 3 1/2 year old minature Jack Russell & she still messes indoors - drives me insane. We toilet her just before bedtime. She sleeps in her bed in the lobby area, next to a nice warm radiator, & she messes or pees most days. If I don't move the door mat she uses that! I've now given up & put newspaper down for her but she doesn't always use that either - I give up. Last summer we bought a kennel & had her staked on a long lead in the garden overnight. She didn't mind (we put a huge teddy in the kennel for her to cuddle up to). I thought that would have got her out the habit, but no. Just as well we love them aye! Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Christmas presents did you really think this out

Posts.Content: Hi SaxxyD, try 2 sites: About the girl & Simply Beach. I got a lovely set of undies from the first & a swim suit from the other. Debenhams had lovely stuff on line but never in my size ;(. Good luck. Xxx
Posts.Title: Help with finding matching MX underwear

Posts.Content: Hello lovely lady, so good to hear you are feeling good about yourself. This cancer thing makes you feel so ancient it's good to be coming out the other side sticking 2 fingers up at it! My undies fitted well (I'm usually an M&S girl) so you should be ok. As I said before, I saw some lovely mastectomy undies online at Debenhams, but I'm an average 36C & they didn't have any in my size ;(. They were a good price too. I've found most mastectomy sites very expensive, but was lucky and got my swimming costume in a sale & it was the last one & fitted beautifully. And a boobie beanie to swim in too. The hair sounds great, mine is only about 1cm at the mo & very grey so I am envious. How long was yours before the cut & colour? Mine has been growing for nearly 4 months & I'm hoping to have a pixie cut by August. You best prepare your other half for a romantic evening - you go girl! But don't forget .... Beauty comes from within & you are already one beautiful woman. Have Fun!! Much love xxx
Posts.Title: Help with finding matching MX underwear

Posts.Content: Best wishes for tomorrow Dorothee & slap that sun cream on 😀xx
Posts.Title: How would money help?

Posts.Content: I think the thanks goes to you Dorothee, you have such a lovely way with words too. 😘X
Posts.Title: How would money help?

Posts.Content: Hi Dorothee, A few things spring to mind; 1. Petrol & Car parking fees. The amount of visits to the hospital before treatment starts is amazing and could be a real drain on finances if things are tight to start with. 2. Help at home post operation / chemo. If my husband hadn't taken so much time off work I don't know how I would have coped. We live rurally & driving my son to & from school, driving miles to & from work & fitting in all the shopping, cooking & cleaning etc was no mean feat. I spent many days on my own post Taxotere just managing to get down the stairs & making a cup of tea & didn't phone the chemo hotline as there was no one to take me if they had said come in. (Yes I do have friends & family but they don't live close by or they work). 3. Massage/ reflexology etc. when stressed out & feeling poorly I would have loved something like this to take the edge off but at £50+ a time & not entitled to sick pay it didn't happen. I raised it with the Onc nurse once but nothing happened. I have a very supportive husband & hate to think what it must be like for people on their own without family nearby & friends available to help. I hope this helps Dorothee. Xxx
Posts.Title: How would money help?

Posts.Content: Hi , I've been told Zinc & Vit E helps hair re growth - I'm taking both . X
Posts.Title: Final FEC tomorrow (woop woop) then Herceptin starts but how long...

Posts.Content: Thanks Julie. I think I keep forgetting that we've poisoned our poor bodies. I keep thinking its all over now, back to normal & then something else happens. I am taking Zinc & Vit E to help hair growth. Have a little fuzz all over & it looks like its growing back grey ;(. I must learn to be more patient. I'm a roll your sleeves up & get on with it type normally! Take care x
Posts.Title: Numb feet??

Posts.Content: Hi Maria, I'm SO pleased for you. How many drains did you have? I hated the drains the most after MX and then ANC. Did you suffer with being unable to stand up straight at all? Must feel great to appear 'normal' again. What part of the country are you in? I'm in Kent & have just been informed that my surgeons have retired; however I think for DIEP flap I'll be sent to East Grinstead & a specialist in micro surgery. After just 2 weeks are you able to do much? I understand its anything from 4 - 12 weeks recovery. Thank you for your positive response, it's reinforced my interest in this type of reconstruction. Best wishes. Xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Judy, sorry to hear that you are suffering. Can they not tell you why your stomach is so bloated with gas? 2 years seems a longtime to suffer - have you stamped your feet? Of course I'd like to hear all positive but it's good to know about the downside too. Before breast cancer I was a very healthy person, with only slight sign of arthritis in R knee. I am still in 2 minds but there is no rush. Thank you for taking the time to reply. I do hope they sort out your problem. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Thank you Sharron, I think you're right about being positive. I've got my referral back to the surgeon at last & will meet him/her in a couple of weeks to discuss. I've recently lost weight due to Metformin trial & don't have such a fat tummy so not sure what they are going to say. But I'm looking fwd to kicking off the discussion. Thanks for your kind words xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Vic, Good luck, I'm sure it will all go well & I'll be thinking of you. Let us know how you get on & enjoy having people running round after you for a change! Take care xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, I've only driven locally a few times lately but need to drive over to Maidstone Hospital next week - better make sure I hit the right pedals aye!! Xx
Posts.Title: Numb feet??

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline, thank you for the info, you sound like a very busy lady. That's what I'm worried about, being incapacitated for 6+ weeks. We live rurally & I have a 10 year old son. My husband says we'll work around it but I just feel after all the running around he's done after MX & chemo it's another big ask. Glad you are feeling well & happy with the results. You take care xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Duffer, great to hear from you. I was referred to Mr Mackey at E Grinstead via Maidstone too. I saw him a few weeks ago & must attend a Keeping Abreast meeting on 8th July before I can see him again & get on the waiting list. I'd love to know how your surgery went & did you have Mr Mackey? Best wishes xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, Thank you for your response - to know that Mr Mackey did an amazing job for you feels me with much more courage to go ahead with the op that I know I truly want & need. Am I right in thinking you are in QVH, E Grinstead at the moment? I do hope that your problem gets sorted. I have heard only good reports about the hospital. I'll try & find your blogs on the BCC site. Wishing you a speedy recovery from your latest procedure. Take care & once again thank you, I do appreciate it. Xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi all, I'm 6 weeks post FEC-T & still suffer with numb finger tips & toes. However after 'getting my legs back' ie not hobbling around like an 80 yr old, & not being able to get out shopping before Xmas - I decided to go to Bluewater today. A tad ambitious. Feet went completely numb in M&S and I hobbled out & collapsed on a bench! Luckily I wasn't driving home. Anyone else experienced this & how long before I truly 'get my legs / feet back'?
Posts.Title: Numb feet??

Posts.Content: You're an inspiration Maria, thank you for all the information. Xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline, thanks for replying. Can I ask what was the scarring like? And how many weeks were you indisposed? I really want this but am scared it may all go wrong. Are you pleased with your new boobie & your flat tummy? Sorry for all the questions! I hope your check goes well later this year. I have family telling me I shouldn't do it but they haven't had their breast removed. Thanks again. Xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm thinking of going for this type of recon & have been googling for info. There are mixed reviews but the majority of people appear to say they're glad they had it done. I'm more scared of this than the mastectomy, I wasn't worried about that, just wanted the cancer out! Any advice, insight would be welcome. Thanks xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Jacky, had my MX July 20012 & had to wait until March 2014 for my DIEP.  Had my nipple reconstruction on 3rd Dec 2014 & am due follow up appointment on 12th Feb.   Just to let you know I am really pleased with it, it does protrude a little more than the real one but they say it shrinks back over time.  When I look in the mirror now I see me as having 2 boobs again, not one and a shaped boob but 2 boobs (if you see what I mean).  I'm just waiting to get the areola tattooed now & I'm all done.  No regrets. Plus the reason I went for it was in a T shirt, I was conscious sometimes that it was obvious (to me anyway) I only had one nipple.  Hope this helps you with your decision whatever you decide. Xx
Posts.Title: NIpple reconstruction dilemma

Posts.Content: Hi, we'll done you, A tip I was given to avoid bad/ sore mouth; use Kingfisher toothpaste & non alcohol based mouthwash. I started routine before any chemotherapy & it worked for me. May not apply to you but I found x 3 FEC fine - carried on almost 'normal'. Docetaxel - more aggressive. I week not getting about anywhere with 1st dose, 3 weeks with 2nd then reduced dose no.3 & 5 weeks not getting about much. Legs just wouldn't 'work'. Also problems with breathlessness & pounding heart but 6 weeks on & legs back now as long as I don't stand on them for too long. Not up to sales shopping LOL. But we're all different & you will get through to the light at the end of the tunnel x
Posts.Title: First Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi, I've stayed about the same weight. Loss some to start with as my appetite waned with chemo, but the inactivity took me back to my normal weight (except the time I put a stone on overnight), when I blew up like Miss Piggy with oedema from the Tax! I've been on Tamoxifen a month now & still around the same weight, but it's early days I suppose. I am trying to eat a little healthier & plan to walk & cycle in the Spring - every little helps! Xx
Posts.Title: Weight?

Posts.Content: Hi Lola. I was fine when I had the MX, only took Paracetemol for pain relief. However you may find getting things over your head difficult so ensure they are lose or button or zip front. It was 3 weeks later when I had the ANC that things got tricky. Beware of 'cording' and ensure you exercise your arm - it's a bugger! I was in overnight only for both ops so if you are in 4 nights the drains should be out before your are discharged. I remember showering with an adapted Sainsbury's bag over my wound & sitting in the bath with my son's Lego boxes piled up beside me with the drain resting on them! The BCN's gave me a floral tie bag for the drain & I pinned it to my gown which gave me free hands. I have had no problem whatsoever with the MX wound, healed really nicely, just a small amount of fluid which got drained once & antibiotics just to be on the safe side. I have been left with a tiny bump of breast and when I wear tops it still looks like I have a cleavage. I asked the BCN if this was done on purpose but she said more by luck. I have bought those new stretchy sports type bras with the pockets & my spongy boob fits in them well & I have worn nothing else. I have only worn my jelly prosthesis once, I find it much heavier. Don't do what I did and contort myself to get bra top on & fully dressed to go home. After the 2nd op in 3 weeks I walked to the car in my PJs & gown ( new black ones I might add)! No one batted an eyelid & I was comfortable & went straight to bed when I got home. Very best wishes to you. Xx
Posts.Title: Weeks following mx

Posts.Content: You're very welcome - I thought exactly the same. Xx
Posts.Title: Beanie boobie

Posts.Content: Jenny don't dread the chemo. The FEC I tolerated really well & was out & about, doing all the shopping, housework, gardening and school runs. It was only the T that knocked me for six. So whilst you still can plan ahead & do as much as you can then enjoy the lazy PJ days when you can't. I found it had an accumulative effect so the last two had me laid up for a while. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Weeks following mx

Posts.Content: Hi Lola ANC is ancillary node clearance. They only do this 2nd op if they find cancer in the sentinel node or the other one or two they remove. I had one macromet & one isolated tumour cell so they did an ANC, I was gutted but apparently it's new research that shows these minute cancer up so really I am lucky! Hoping you are lucky and yours are clear, especially after the chemo. My lobular cancer was large so they just went straight in with mastectomy. I must say though, I didn't really understand why I had the 'bubble test' where they took another 3 painful biopsies, then the sentinel node & a few others removed, then the 2nd op. thought the bubble test was to see whether you had them all out or not?? I say thank God for mammograms or I wouldn't of had a clue & it had obviously just started to spread to nodes. Hope this helps. Xx Good luck Nikki too xx
Posts.Title: Weeks following mx

Posts.Content: Hi, don't beat yourself up. I feel very similar. Diagnosed April 2012, MX June, ANC July, chemo Aug - end Nov. the Tax knocked me for six & I barely left the house for 5-6 weeks. No Xmas shopping! I'm only just feeling like the old me (on a good day)! Seeing GP Mon & not sure what she'll say about returning to work (I only work PT now after being made redundant in 2011). Some days, now, I'm full of confidence, hope, energy & others I don't want to leave the house & wonder how I can return to work. I think it's only now that we can take stock of the roller coaster ride we've been on; & some days the enormity of it hits us. I'm trying to allow myself several weeks to 'convaless' & get back into the swing of things. Not too much to ask is it! So be kind to yourself. Xxx
Posts.Title: finished rads 3 weeks ago - fatigue

Posts.Content: Hi! For all those who've had a mastectomy & like to swim I managed to get a 'beanie' swim boobie from a site for just £12.99. I know I can't put a link but google 'About The Girl', mastectomy swimsuits. No worries about ruining my prostheses & it's lightweight & easy to pack for holidays too. Xx
Posts.Title: Beanie boobie

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, no I wasn't. Just the little foam one post op & then the proper prostheses. I wasn't given an introduction to chemo either like lots of you ladies seem to have, or offered the cold cap. Depends what area you are in I think. Xx
Posts.Title: Beanie boobie

Posts.Content: Wow Carol, sounds like we should all go get treatment in France!
Posts.Title: Weeks following mx

Posts.Content: Hi Numbness in my fingertips & toes has only just gone (took over 3 months from end of chemo). My GP took blood to check Vit B12 & said if that was low she could prescribe some which would help matters. Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Neuropathy on my feet and hands and exercise

Posts.Content: Hi Jane, It is very lightweight, a light cotton fabric with tiny lightweight non absorbent balls inside. Just need to dry the cotton after swimming. If I were you I'd phone them direct & make enquiries. They were helpful to me & rang & suggested I needed a different size knicker to match a mastectomy bra I'd ordered. I was very pleased with my undies. To be honest when I put my mastectomy swimsuit on, as it is black across the bust, you had to look hard before you realised I was lopsided. But I knew I was & that mattered to me. Hence the beanie. You can purchase proper swim prostheses but on all the sites I've seen they are expensive. Although someone commented that their BCN gave them a swim prostheses too. So maybe ask? Must admit I've been shocked at how expensive mastectomy swimsuits can be on some sites. I'm an 'average' 36C & most are out of stock in this size. Debenhams on line had a wonderful selection of mastectomy bras & not one available in my size! Good prices too. I decided 'I'm worth it' in the end & treated myself on other sites ;0) Hope you find something suitable - good luck xxx PS. George @ ASDA are apparently now selling a mastectomy swimsuit at a very reasonable £12 - some reviews rave about it, some say it doesn't offer much support. But for anyone on a budget & not working at the moment it's an option.
Posts.Title: Beanie boobie

Posts.Content: Hi, I used Kingfisher toothpaste & Cordosyl mouthwash (both from supermarket) & had no problem with mouth & throat. Best wishes x
Posts.Title: sore mouth and throat

Posts.Content: Hi, I was diagnosed with invasive lobular cancer last April & I too had to wait for MRI results. I too remember thinking "get this out of me as soon as you can"! I was told they are obliged to operate within 30 days of full diagnosis & that fell true for me. Apparently they get a much better view of the cancer from the MRI before they operate & know what they are dealing with. Then of course you have to wait for the histology of the tumour. The BCNs told me that the cancer didn't grow that quickly & not to worry. At least you have the reassurance afterwards that the tumour is contained. Be prepared to lie face down in the scanner & take a distracting CD for them to play for you. They really do work hard on getting an accurate diagnosis in order to give you an individually tailored treatment plan. Good to hear you are thinking positively, I believe that helps our recovery. Fingers crossed & best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Well didn't expect those results

Posts.Content: SaxxyD: sorry to hear your latest update; hope your scan will put your mind at rest. Ethel: great to hear your results were good. Take care ladies ((( big hugs))) xxx
Posts.Title: Postponing more chemo...have I made right decision?

Posts.Content: Hi Tokes, from what you describe I have the same. No problem at all with my comfy or prosthesis. In fact I think it's a bonus as when wearing tops I still look like I have a cleavage. Just have to be careful they aren't too low cut as not a pretty sight when you bend down! LOL. Best wishes xxx
Posts.Title: Flat chest?

Posts.Content: http://bit.ly/WJurK4
Posts.Title: Please read attached link (all those on Tamoxifen)

Posts.Content: Try this: http://www.breastcancercampaign.org/news-and-media/press-releases/women’s-lives-at-risk-as-they-stop-taking-breast-cancer-treatment-too
Posts.Title: Please read attached link (all those on Tamoxifen)

Posts.Content: Hi, I've taken Tamoxifen since 28th Dec with no real side effects. I do get a little hot now & again but nothing too bad. I take them when I get up in the morning along with my Metformin trial pill & Vit pills. Funny Dorothee, I've noticed I go to bed much later now too, but then I put this down to not getting up at 6.30am 6 days a week! Maybe not! I must say I was very dubious about taking them, and left it until post Xmas for that reason, but I needn't of worried. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: tamoxifen advice

Posts.Content: Thanks Sue. I'm only on day 3 of Tamoxifen but have read that taking it at night can help with hot sweats so may do this if they become a problem. Xx
Posts.Title: Anyone on the Metformin Trial?

Posts.Content: Hi, just wondered if you lived in Wadhurst, Kent? Not too far from me. X
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer has spread to nodes, panicking

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm new to this site. In brief I was diagnosed with invasive lobular cancer, L breast, in April 2012. T2. L mastectomy June 2012, L ancillary node clearance July 2012. Fec-T Aug - Nov . Just started Tamoxifen (5yrs). Declined radiotherapy trial. Due to start Metformin trial Jan 2013. Was wondering if anyone else is on this trial & has any comments or advice? Thanks.
Posts.Title: Anyone on the Metformin Trial?

Posts.Content: Hi, I was asked to join the trial at my last Onc appt. apparently there is research that suggests Metformin helps stop recurrence. Obviously from people who are diabetic & taking Metformin. My cancer is ER+ and PR+. I never realised Insulin is a hormone! So I've agreed to take part but won't know if I'm on Metformin or a placebo. Just hoping I don't get many side affects from Metformin as I've just started Tamoxifen & am awaiting symptoms to hit!
Posts.Title: Anyone on the Metformin Trial?

Posts.Content: Thanks Sue x
Posts.Title: Anyone on the Metformin Trial?

Posts.Content: Hi, please look up SUPREMO Trial. I'm in Kent & borderline with only sentinel node involvement (1 macromet, 1 micromet & an ITC. There is some thought that radiotherapy would be unnecessary, especially as I had FEC-T. I went to see consultant radiologist & nurse to get full details - consultant wanted me on trial ( although a copy of his letter blatantly said I didn't really need it) & nurse told me lots more negatives of treatment. Mine would have been left side & I was worried about possible damage to heart & lungs. Plus I didn't realise you can only have it once, so if I got a recurrence in the future & I'd already had radiotherapy (maybe unnecessarily) I wouldn't be able to have it then. So I made up my mind not to have it & I'm glad after chemo that I didn't (at this point). They put me on Metformin trial & I was happy to do that (but that's another story & my body is not tolerating the drug but it has huge pluses in preventing recurrence) . Whatever you decide good luck. I think it's a personal choice but if you feel you want/need it then fight for it. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Finished fec and start tax on Wednesday but feeling really nervous...

Posts.Content: Thanks Sascha, very interesting! X
Posts.Title: Anyone on the Metformin Trial?

Posts.Content: Best wishes to you too & I hope the Metformin proves a positive addition to our fight with cancer. Xx Sent from my iPad
Posts.Title: Anyone on the Metformin Trial?

Posts.Content: How wonderfully put Sassy71. I was going to reply but you've said it all. ((Big hugs)) Kaw & everyone else having a s****y day. Xxx
Posts.Title: Really fed up

Posts.Content: Hi, try Suzi wigs in Thurruck shopping centre. Xx
Posts.Title: Real hair wig info required

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca, When my Oncologist put me on Tamoxifen she said any sign of bleeding get back in touch as quickly as possible (as I think a rare side effect is cancer of the womb). I'm not sure if it's the same with Letrozole but take a look at the details in the packet & if it's in there then bang their door down! I'm sure the BCN would help too. At least it's not Friday! Will be thinking of you & hope you get an answer soon. Take care xx
Posts.Title: Who you gonna call?

Posts.Content: LOL, thanks George 😀.
Posts.Title: Did anyone else develop a teensy consultant crush during their treatment...

Posts.Content: Ooh, I say ....... Just came to bed early with a cuppa & choccie biccie & this popped up on my iPad - smiling now too ;0). Can't say I fancy my consultant, but he's pleasant enough, but it's amazing how quickly you get used to standing in front of 'strange men' half naked! George - don't suppose you have one of George Clooney or Paul Hollywood? ✌️
Posts.Title: Did anyone else develop a teensy consultant crush during their treatment...

Posts.Content: Ooh, I say ....... Just came to bed early with a cuppa & choccie biccie & this popped up on my iPad - smiling now too ;0). Can't say I fancy my consultant, but he's pleasant enough, but it's amazing how quickly you get used to standing in front of 'strange men' half naked! George - don't suppose you have one of George Clooney or Paul Hollywood? ✌️
Posts.Title: Did anyone else develop a teensy consultant crush during their treatment...

Posts.Content: LOL, thanks George 😀.
Posts.Title: Did anyone else develop a teensy consultant crush during their treatment...

Posts.Content: Hi Deidre, yes sounds like peripheral neuropathy to me. I got it with my second Docetaxel dose & they lowered my final dose. You must tell your Onc as they will probably lower yours. I'm now 11 weeks post FEC-T & still have numb fingers & toes although it is getting better VERY gradually. My feet used to go totally numb when I was walking! GP says tips of fingers may always feel a bit numb. However she did say is no better in a few weeks she'll check my Vit B12 levels & maybe prescribe something to help. On a brighter note I now have a covering of 'baby' hair, albeit salt & pepper in colour & I've just noticed that I now also have some eyebrows too, but alas no eyelashes yet. So it is doable & things do get better. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: new symptom last night sensitivity in in my fingertips for hot water...

Posts.Content: Hi Dolphin woman LOL Can I ask do you go swimming with a bald head? I'd love to swim at the mo but don't want to frighten anyone, especially the children! I'm 6wks post chemo, no rads planned. Just bum fluff on head at the mo. Also skin is dry & not sure if chlorine will affect it? Also can I wear my 'jelly' prosthesis in the pool? Sorry, such a lot of questions. Well done you for being so pro active. Well done Keira too! PS sorry not been on site much, changing Sky broadband to BT & not up & running but just discovered can get some reception on iPhone (via 3G???).
Posts.Title: Exercise

Posts.Content: Hi Dolphin woman LOL Can I ask do you go swimming with a bald head? I'd love to swim at the mo but don't want to frighten anyone, especially the children! I'm 6wks post chemo, no rads planned. Just bum fluff on head at the mo. Also skin is dry & not sure if chlorine will affect it? Also can I wear my 'jelly' prosthesis in the pool? Sorry, such a lot of questions. Well done you for being so pro active. Well done Keira too! PS sorry not been on site much, changing Sky broadband to BT & not up & running but just discovered can get some reception on iPhone (via 3G???).
Posts.Title: Exercise

Posts.Content: Hi, I had MX, ANC then FEC-T. I found the FEC easy, carried on as normal apart from a few days but the 'T' (Docetaxel) knocked me for six. But we're all different & have different doses. It's the FEC that gives you hair loss. Mine started coming back before my last Tax. It's all doable & to be honest I'm 11 weeks post chemo now and almost back to normal. Remember to look after yourself, keep hydrated & eat healthily. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Taxol Herceptin then FEC

Posts.Content: Thanks G&J - made me cry, so related to it emotionally. Xx
Posts.Title: Turning Corners and a Bit of Inspiration :-)

Posts.Content: Yep, I endorse that Kate, I use it all the time & it is known to be used as a repellent amongst Avon women. It really does smell lovely too & is not sticky & leaves skin feeling lovely x
Posts.Title: Lymphodema risk and insect repellent

Posts.Content: Hi Keira, try not to worry - they give you anti sickness intravenously plus steroids for anti sickness & send you home with anti sickness tablets. Take them whether you feel nauseous or not & you should be fine. Once you know what to expect your anxiety will lessen. The time will whizz round & it will soon be behind you. Best wishes xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling nervous of my first fec chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, in brief - I got made redundant then diagnosed with cancer 4 months after starting a new PT job which wouldn't pay sick pay. I applied for ESA was turned down but they sent a huge form for me to complete so I rang them & they said they'd changed their mind! Then because of cancer diagnosis they put you into their 'special group' & up payments to £105 per week. It did take around 3 months before I got any payments though. They reviewed after a while and another huge form to complete but then they said they didn't even want to see sick certificates, but obviously my employers did. So don't always be put off immediately, sometimes you have to push. And if you've worked hard & paid your taxes all your adult life you're entitled to it. Good luck xx PS. Don't forget to ask your GP to register you for Medical Exemption so your prescriptions are free for the next 5 years.
Posts.Title: Sick pay

Posts.Content: Several months before diagnosis my dentist asked if I was well or felt stressed, I said I was fine.  She said if my gums start bleeding to return.  The day before my chemo started, around 3 months later, I had a tooth removed as there was a problem with it & they wanted to re-do the root canal.  Now ai'm wondering ......
Posts.Title: Root canal and cancer

Posts.Content: Hi, I had MX mid June, ANC early July & started chemo 9th August. I'm sure they won't keep you waiting long. Best wishes xx
Posts.Title: Chemo after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi, what a lovely photo & wig; looks natural to me. I'm 7 weeks post FEC-T now & still only have 'fluff'. Do you mind me asking how long it took you to grow to a suitable length to go without your wig? I still have that greyish 'chemo' look & have maybe one or two photos of me in my wig or bald. Not a time I want to catalogue & remember really! Does anyone else have the dark eyes too? Like dark circles around your eyes, can't wait for them to go. Well done you - another milestone. This cancer has made us stronger women. Take care xx
Posts.Title: Twiggy's up for sale (my wig :-)) )

Posts.Content: Hi Susy, good news that you have a date, use the waiting time to get those odd jobs done so that you can convalesce after your op. just a bit more info, I believe you will be 'upgraded' to the 'seriously ill' group & benefit goes up to £105.50 a week. Not a huge amount but every little counts! Don't forget to get a form from your GP to get your medical exemption certificate for the next 5 years - you'll be amazed how many lotions & potions you may need in the future & prescriptions are expensive. Enjoy the boxing as you won't be doing that for a while after surgery. I too have realised that it was better I wasn't in a job I no longer enjoyed & zapped my energy & strength. I may no longer earn so much but am more relaxed & enjoying life & taking time to stop & smell the roses for a change. As you say, sometimes things happen for a reason. The MacMillan team can also provide you with information on financial help so give them a ring. Best wishes to you. ((Hugs)) xxx. PS. My benefit took months to come through so be prepared & try not to stress xx
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - Scared and loosing faith in the system fast

Posts.Content: Hi Susy, I too was diagnosed with invasive lobular cancer G2 T1. Like SaxxyD I too was told straightaway that immediate reconstruction was not an option. I was also told that this type of cancer is hard to detect as you don't have a 'lump' as such - it is more like deep down hardening of tissue; I beat myself up for a time thinking I should have noticed earlier but it really is best to put all your energies into kicking cancer's butt! I too am based in Kent & for the type of recon you want they refer you to the McIndoe centre at East Grinstead hospital where the specialists are. I'm currently waiting for my appointment. I was made redundant not long before my diagnosis & lost my private medical cover, but to be honest the NHS has been great & their guidelines are to operate within 30 days of full diagnosis. I'm sure you will get your MX done ASAP then you will have time to think about what you will have done & where best to be referred. Best wishes xxx
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - Scared and loosing faith in the system fast

Posts.Content: Hi, if my experience can help you ... I finished chemo end Nov 2012 , (MX June & ANC July 2012). 3 month Onc check Oct, (few questions & an examination) and got 1 yr check (mammogram) through for mid July 2013. However, I pushed for referral for recon & got an April appt with breast surgeon. Slightly alarmed when I got called through for a mammogram, questioned this but was assured, yes, I was to have one. Saw Dr & was told they decided as I was there they'd bump my 1 yr check fwd so I got it 1 yr from diagnosis rather than last op. So I got the mammogram, questions & an examination of the mastectomy area & other breast & told all clear. I must say at this point I felt 'is that it'? How do they know its gone? However, I'm on a Metformin Trial & get regular checks for this too & had one a week ago. They took 10 phials of blood, asked questions & I got a very thorough examination from the research doctor. She felt my clavicle & neck too. I felt much more reassured when I'd left that I was all clear. I think they can tell a lot from blood results as to if there is something going on inside. They have now bumped my next Oncologist check from Oct to Dec to coincide with the research checks so please don't be too worried & ask for your appt to be moved away from the Xmas period if this is upsetting you. Meantime, you can always call your BCN if you have any worries. I must admit if I've had any other niggles I now go straight to GP, just in case. Please try to stop worrying as I truly believe that a positive mind helps us along our path. Hope this info helps you, even a little. Please do phone & re-arrange your appts if it takes away some stress. Take care Hugs xxx
Posts.Title: My Good News

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea, I'm from the 'school of 2012' & have just watched a couple of your videos. Just to say how beautiful you look bald & admire your make up skills. Do you do this professionally, if not you're a natural! Wishing you a crisis free 'journey' on this roller coaster. Keep on smiling! X
Posts.Title: Makeup tutorials on you tube for us chemo girls

Posts.Content: Hi, sorry but I think your GP is out of order. Going through chemo is no walk in the park! My GP is very tough about signing sick certificates but the benefits dept rang me and told me to ask my GP for x 2 lots of 3 month sick certificates ( from date of op onwards; takes a good time before it comes through) - I questioned it & they said due to BC they put you in the 'seriously ill' category. So I did what they asked & GP did as she was told! She also told ATOS not to call me for assessment as chemo wasn't that type of illness. GP has extended them since & I hope to return to P-T work in the not too distant future. Also once Benefits put you in their 'seriously ill' box they enhance the SSP. It's not the same as your salary but every little helps. They also told me they didn't want sick certs anymore but I have had to complete two huge forms. However work still require the sick certs. Don't be bullied into working when you feel truly awful. I was expecting to work on good days but my manager was horrified when I mentioned it. So I went along with what I was told & feel I have benefited from it & given my body time to heal. Best wishes & take care of yourself. Xx
Posts.Title: Fit notes

Posts.Content: Hi, just to butt in to say my lymphoedema nurse told me to go to GP & ask to have some antibiotics prescribed (with a lengthy expiry date) to keep at home for any emergencies such as bites & cuts. She was also insistent that these be taken for 2 weeks & not just one. I've just checked mine & they expire soon so I will be putting in a repeat prescription. I've packed them for holiday & it gives me peace of mind. My GP was happy to do this. Take care xx

Posts.Content: Well done George - well deserved!  ✋ pat on the back!  X

Posts.Content: Godd luck & best wishes to all you lovely tanning ladies, xxx
Posts.Title: Last hurdle!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hello ladies, I'm new to this site and didn't know Annabel but your posts really touch my heart. I'm honoured to have 'met' you all. You all have beautiful hearts. Bless you xxx
Posts.Title: Feels empty here

Posts.Content: Happy New Year Caroline. I'm new to this site. Just finished treatment & looking fwd to a better 2013. Best wishes to you all xxx
Posts.Title: new year onwards and upwards

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca, I can't believe it when people say "but you're Ok now aren't you, you've had all your treatment". I politely remind them I an on Tamoxifen for 5 or 10 years & a Metformin trial, and live with all the side effects daily! I go in for my DIEP tomorrow & was told last Friday - "oh you'll be fine, sounds the same as a Caesarian"! You gotta laugh! Take care Blue Tit xx (Not been on for a while but still getting emails)
Posts.Title: Most outrageous, ridiculous etc

Posts.Content: Congratulations!!!!!
Posts.Title: new year onwards and upwards

Posts.Content: Hi Ali, I've only been taking since 28 Dec & don't think I have any symptoms that I didn't have beforehand. But maybe it's not in my system properly yet. I delayed taking it until after Xmas because I thought I'd have horrible side effects. My 'brand' is also the Wokhardt so maybe that's why. I'm not sure if I'm in the menopause or not. Occasionally feel a little hot but not from head to toe & no night sweats ( fingers crossed). My GP said if I do she can give me something to help anyway. Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen help please

Posts.Content: Hi Shelley, I can only advise you what I was told last week by my specialist Lymphodema nurse. I told her at Xmas I ballooned like Miss Piggy; particularly legs, ankles, feet & then my left arm joined in where I had had the MX & ANC. She made it quite clear that she was & only ever would be interested in Lymphodema associated at the site where the lymph nodes were removed. Hope this helps. Take care & mention it to your GP or consultant. Xx
Posts.Title: Lymphodema question

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, have answered your PM (seems I can do that but not initiate one)?? PS said I can have the DIEP, need to attend a Keeping Abreast meeting at E Grinstead on 8th July first, then one more visit with him & he'll put me on his waiting list (3 -6 months). I feel better now Ive been & seen him & I know it's what I want. Yes I'm doing the Race For Life on 9th June at Dunorlan Park, T Wells with my Mum, 2 sisters, daughter, niece & 2 friends (dressed as pink fairies)!! Not really 'training' but keeping busy back at work P-T, housework & gardening & as I had a tax rebate bought myself a lovely Dutch bicycle & will be out on that on fair weather days. Really good to hear from you. Take care . Much love to all you strong ladies especially you, Winston, SaxxyD, Ethel, Dorethee, Mother 47 et al. Xxx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, lovely to see you posting and bathing in the light at the end of the tunnel. I'm not having any luck PM on this site at the moment, maybe it's the ipad? I sent SaxxyD a PM recently updating her on my consultation with the plastic surgeon but not sure she received it. Anyhow just wanted to wish you well in The Race for Life. Take care xxx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: Hi Ethel, lovely to hear from you, so upbeat - 11 year olds certainly keep us on our toes! Loved the WTH piece. Being a member of this club certainly makes you cherish what you have. Hi Kate, always there with positive advice. Xxx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: Hi Ethel, so you are on the real thing after all, I'm so pleased as I remember you saying you wished you were but didn't think so as you had no side affects. I presume as you are having more surgery they had to find out if you had to stop medication or not? I had an horrendous time & am obviously on the real thing. I was home bound for a while & had to stop it for a month & am now just on half the daily dose, which my body can tolerate. If I'm going out I don't take my Metformin until I get home as it can still have an effect on my digestive system. I tried to get them to give me Metformin Slow Release which is coated & doesn't have this effect but they won't as its not part of the trial. My GP was very supportive. If the trial has a positive outcome I'm sure she'll prescribe it for me (I think it's x 3 times expensive though). Keep us up to date with how you get on. Take care xxx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, Dorothee you have such a wonderful way with words - brilliant! Xxx
